The Beacon Hotel is the place to go if you are a musician or in the industry.It is situated steps away from the famous Beacon Theatre.This hotel has lots of atmosphere.It looks old and feels old but that is it's charm.The rooms are spacious by NY standards and are priced resonably.They are also very clean and fresh.The staff is reasonable and attentive.Our room had a kitchenette.The refrigerator made a loud irritating noise every time it started.I discovered this the morning I woke up in the room.I let the front staff know and it was replaced quickly.That is the mark of a well run hotel.
This property is located a short walk from a host of great restaurants and attractions.It is remakably quiet especialy for being on a busy street.My wife and I love it here.Did I mention that there is some great shopping within walking distance?

title: “Ideal location and facilities”
text: This was our first long-haul trip so everything about the hotel and NYC was new. The room was really spacious and spotlessly clean. There was a little kitchenette area in the room with coffee machine and guest laundry facilities (washers and dryers) just down the corridor. The staff were very helpful, the internet/printer facility in the lobby was a bonus for printing our return boarding passes and the Viand cafe next door offered great value, excellent service and a really wide choice of food at all times of the day. With Fairway supermarket opposite and 72nd street subway just a couple of minutes walk away, the location could not have been better: just one stop to Times Square on the downtown express line. We bought a weekly subway ticket ($29) from the machine in Grand Central Station and made the most of this fabulous and friendly city.

title: “Feels like a low grade Hyatt”
text:
My entire family gathered at this hotel for a wedding. The rooms definitely need to be upgraded as the bathroom sink was constantly leaking. The elevators had constant problems. The Bar had constant problems getting proper drinks on time. The pool area is small , therefore to crowded to get much fun. (although i have to say that at least the pool was not chlorine based they are savvy to use salt water) When ordering food and beverages for a small group of 6 we had to wait for an hour or more. The work out area was ok. This is a Four Seasons Hotel and this was not even close to being in that caliber. To be fair I have to say that the service was excellent from the doormen to the desk. The food at the restaurant was ok. 
The restaurants around this hotel are very good. The Art Museum is so amazing and very close to get to. Over all , however, it was an expensive experience and certainly would not commend this hotel if you are planning on having a top notch time.

title: “Needs a facelift”
text: We stay here frequently due to convenience and overall the property is good. However, it is tired and needs a facelift. I am sure it is so busy that taking time to redo the property is hard. The rooms are typical rooms, however, last time we stayed in a very small, very cramped, single queen bed room. I specifically asked not to have that room this time. At first, they said that they had no other rooms, then after telling them that our company has events here and guests here constantly, they gave us a better room. The staff is always nice and I love the lady that has done my pedicures several times. If you need to stay downtown, this is the best hotel. However, always crowded and seems tired.

title: “best hotel”
text: I was able to stay at the ICON for two nights on the 9th floor - king bed. From the moment I entered valet parking and went to my room, the hotel staff were courteous and respectful which was a great feeling. I think this hotel is gorgeous - from the entry, elevators, hall way to the rooms, and especially the room decor. I feel like this is the nicest hotel that I have stayed in. I will DEFINITELY stay here again! Thank you, hotel ICON!

title: “Impressive”
text: My wife and I stayed at the Icon in Houston on Septemeber 24th after returning from our awesome seven day cruise. We had used an outside agency to reserve a room somewhere downtown. Our bid landed us here, I feared the worse and was kicking myself for using the service. However I must say the Hotel greatly proved me wrong. The Icon Hotel is in great shape and even coming from a mans point of view somewhat beautiful. Probably one of the best hotel's I've stayed in, in a long time. Great service, great accommodations. The only draw back I found was parking. I've learned that overnight parking in downtown houston is outragous. However I was not pleased with the charge of $30 to park. I took the risk with a rental car and did street parking and switched to a private lot in the am for $6.

title: “Sexy, fun, everything at your fingertips”
text: Hotel Sorella at Citycentre Houston is a sister property to Hotel Valencia Riverwalk in San Antonio. Hotel Sorella may even trump Hotel Valencia! Sorella is very contemporary, sleek and simple in its design, masculine decor touches and overall inviting and warm. The hotel staff is beyond accommodating, and the rooms are spacious complete with flat panel TVs, iPod docks, and seriously comfy furniture. We stayed in a room with a view of the common area in front of the hotel. The common area is a beautiful, inviting, green area constantly teeming with activity. During the evening, we had a wonderful view of a live band and lots of people dancing and enjoying the night. The following morning, the common area played host to a slew of families with children and dogs on one end and the other end housed a group of people doing aerobics and stretching/strengthening exercises. Walking out of the hotel on the back side, we spotted MULTIPLE exotic cars throughout our stay parked in the valet area. Each time we exited the hotel through those doors, we spotted different cars including Ferraris, Lamborghinis, Porsches, Audi R8, etc. It was basically a free high end car show with our stay. The Houston Motor Club is housed within Citycentre, and there's always a gorgeous car somewhere to drool over. The M Club Bar and Lounge is a MUST SEE for couples wanting a VERY SEXY nightclub and a fascinating study in human nature. ;) You will have your choice of fine dining, excellent shopping, and entertainment. Everything you'll need is within walking distance, and Citycentre feels like a self-contained Stepford village catering to your every whim. You will NOT be disappointed with Hotel Sorella and the Citycentre experience. We can't wait to go back!!!

title: “Nice hotel”
text:
Highly recommended. 
Room: – spacious, clean, big bed, very clean bathroom.
Hotel: good location in ‘City Centre’, free shuttle bus service within 5 miles
Service: check-in and check-out very fast, outstanding customer service
Internet: free wi-fi in your room.
Breakfast: continental

title: “Um...it's just okay.”
text:
We were visitors at the University of Houston and a department at the school booked us in the hotel. 
1. The hotel is a bit more dated then the Trip Advisor review page reveals. The exterior is just okay and the interior lobby is a symphony of green carpet from the 70's.
2. The staff was really nice, helpful. They are students at the University.
3. Hotel hallways were nice - more updated - someone did some renovating here - then you slide the card into your room door - and...well, let's just say it ain't the Hilton! Oh, wait - it was the Hilton!
4. Our room was small and weirdly spaced, there was a weird sliding closet and a giant vent above one of our beds. The TV was tiny - the reviews are right - it was laughable! I laughed.
5. At 3am our neighbor came home. We heard his whole conversation for the next hour. Seriously - it was like he was in the room with us. We determined that the vent was to blame. We mentioned it to the front desk, their response: "We're very sorry"
6. Cold water. Came in to take a shower after a long day - after letting the water run for about 10 minutes the temperature never went from cold to hot. Called the front desk to complain, the response "I never heard that before."
7. The restaurant was questionable...a grand white iceberg salad was delivered with chemical carrot slices, the menu seemed to be aiming at something - but overall was pretty random. The food was just okay...just like everything else at the University of Texas Hilton - just okay...
8. Parking system is kind of dated. Visitors get video game tokens to feed the parking machine. One for every exit.
9. Nice sewing kits though.

title: “Hotel good, Eric's Restaurant not the best”
text:
I have stayed at the Hilton at the Univ. of Houston about 5 or 6 times since 2006. While the hotel itself is fine - my rooms have always been comfortable and clean, no noise issues for me. My coworkers complained about not enough hot water one morning during our recent stay from March 5-6. I have also eaten at Eric's restaurant in the hotel several times since 2006. The experience at the restaurant has definitely been uneven, especially during this last stay March 5-6, 2008. The service was slow on for both breakfast and dinner. My food at dinner was acceptable, but one of my coworkers returned what she ordered for dinner. A manager should have come out to see what the problem is when a customer returns a meal. At breakfast the next day I discovered a smashed tomato in the carpeting that was left over when the restaurant was not properly cleaned from the night before. This is not a good sanitary procedure. 
The hotel is fine, but if you are going to be in Houston for more than a day or two, you might want to explore other dining options than Eric's.

title: “Absolutely wonderful!!!”
text: My husband and I went away for a few days and when we checked in we were upgraded from a Deluxe room to an Executive Club Suite! The room was on the 14th floor and was beautiful with a large living area and large bedroom. The balcony was phenomenal! There were 2 mini fridges and a wonderful Bose stereo system. The pool area was nice where we relaxed and laid out and watched the stars. We also took advantage of the club room that was very. Ice to grab chips and driinks. We loved the skywalk to the mall and Cheesecake Factory. Overall it was great staff, not busy, great rate, and very clean!

title: “Modern and bright”
text:
I found the Westin Memorial City to be a fine hotel. While it is a long way from the IAH, if you need to be in that part of Houston, then I would recommend this hotel. The staff were amazingly friendly, the room was spacious and well appointed. On my list of must haves:
Fluffy towels: 3 stars, just middle of the road
Breakfast: 4 stars, you have a number of choices whether in the hotel or across the street
Free internet: 1 star. Just available in the lobby. However, given the price of the room, the $10/day fee is well mitigated.
Pillows: 4 stars: plenty and comfortable
Water pressure: 5 stars, excellent.

title: “Beautiful and so Comfy!”
text: We were fortunate to have a beautiful suite on the 20th floor. Traditional in design, the room was very comfortable and luxurious. The service was excellent. I would definitely recommend it to others. This was a business trip for my husband and his partners, but the wives tagged along for the shopping and theatre! So it was business and pleasure.

title: “Staying at the Sherry Netherland Hotel”
text: The room was gorgeous, beautifully decorated, the service was excellent, the view from the window remarkable, the localization excellent. I do recommend staying at the Sherry Netherland Hotel if you go to New York.

title: “Grab a special and Live a Dream!”
text:
I just got back from my Labor Day weekend at The Sherry and will go again in a heart-beat when the next special comes along. 
I like the challenge of finding 5-star deals on a budget. When I also manage to get the same exceptional service and attention as those who can easily afford such luxury, it's a very rare combination indeed. But the Sherry hit a home run on both counts and I think that I've found my special go-to place to stay. From the youngest to the oldest employee, from the early morning/late night front desk staff to every single elevator captain and bellop, ALL were unfailingly polite and cheerful! You really get the sense that they love their jobs and they are super happy to serve. Each time my mother and I came through the door, I felt as though we were truly welcomed "home". In fact, it got to be nothing to just hang out in the lobby and get the best tips on where to shop or get the best coffee and brunch. I am serious...this staff can give the top hotels in NYC some lessons in true hospitality.
Room 211, which I think was a wonderful upgrade on their part, is fit for any special occasion. Spacious, beautifully appointed with a big screen TV and a gazillion cable stations, a wonderful large bathroom, lots of light , and a birds-eye view of the CBS Early Show studio....not to mention a corner of the famous corner anchored by The Plaza Hotel. There were times when we just felt like "staying put", but we didn't miss out on the buzz of the city. It was right outside to see!
Want to get away quick? The subway stop is right around the corner of the hotel. You can be in Union Square (HUGE Filene's and Whole Foods Market) in less than 25-minutes. Feel like you need to commit to an East Side -vs-West Side experience? Don't bother. You can do both without much effort with cabs and cross-town buses all around -- not to mention horse drawn carriages. An escape to the more magical? Famous Central Park, which can seem postively other-worldly in the quiet morning sunlight, is steps aways.
When in NYC, we usually stay at The Casablanca, The Elysee, and The Lucerne. Each has a lot to recommend it. But I honestly have to say that I am going to take time to check out the Sherry first before I look elsewhere from now on. If you really want to kick your NYC experience up a notch, you should too. You'll be really glad that you did!

title: “traditional elegance”
text: With its wonderful location off Central Park, this very traditionally elegant hotel has a lot to offer. Be careful about room selection, the variation is greater than most hotels. Staff is efficient if slightly stiff. Pricey but probably worth it.

title: “Most personal hotel I've ever stayed in”
text: Amazing personal service, they make you feel right at home

title: “BEST KEPT SECRET IN NY”
text: Stayed 3 nights this past weekend. Great Hotel...spacious room. Short walk to Lex and 53rd subway with many connections. Short walk to famous PJ Clarkes grill as well. Very attentive and friendly staff. The Doorman was exceptional with his great tips on restaurants. After very hot days spend in the subway and all over Manhattan, it was a pleasure to find the room ice cold to relax and rest before dinner. Will come back for sure.

title: “Very happy - would stay here again”
text: We had a 2 roomed suite for 3 people. I was surprised by how spacious it was. We had a bathroom with a tub and a shower over it, a small kitchen with a microwave, coffe maker, fridge etc and a sitting area. Big tv in both rooms and plenty storage space. The free wifi worked well. I asked for a high room at the back and we didn't have any traffic noise. Beds were extremely comfortable. Housekeeping was very good and the reception staff were friendly. They lent us umbrellas when we had a wet day. The lifts were fast and we never had to wait. The free breakfast was fine but was very carb-heavy. Coffee, juice, yogurt, cereal, pastries, bread etc. No fruit, so I wouldn't have wanted to eat there for more than a few days. Having said that the quality was very good.

title: “Courteous, Clean, Convenient”
text: This hotel location worked for us. Walk north to the park and shopping, south to more shopping, close to museums, shows, library, and plenty of restaurants. The staff was courteous,hotel was clean, there is a business center, no need for anything more. This is on our list of favorites hotels in NYC.

title: “Nice room, but not much more in this hotel”
text: Centrally located, not far from Times square and close to 5th avenue. The room was fresh and good, not large though. There was a tiny bar/restaurant in the hotel, but this was not very good in my opinion. Lacking almost everything at breakfast, for instance. There is a perfect breakfast place close by, so no worries. Can recommend for a trip for a couple or family, but a bit unpractical for larger group when the hotel itself has nothing to offer.

title: “"Charming Hotel in Times Square Area"”
text: When staying in the Times Square area, we usually stay at one of our favorite hotels down the block and always wanted to try The Iroquois Hotel. I'm so glad we did. The staff is professional and polite. Upon checking in we were upgraded to the Presidential Suite. I like booking rooms with separate seating area, so I had originally booked a smaller suite. Well, I couldn't believe when we walked into this suite! It was absolutely wonderful! Living room, dining room, kitchen and bedroom. There was just one thing. The bathroom stall shower was tiny. But if you like to take a bath, it has jacuzzi. The decor is elegant and the bed very cozy. I don't sleep very well in hotel rooms, but I did in this bed. Until the morning when a jackhammer woke us up. They were opening up the street below the hotel. Even with the construction going on, we had a wonderful stay because the room was so nice.

title: “Centrally Located--Great Service--Reasonable Price”
text: We stayed five nights and had a room facing the street on the 12th floor. It was very quiet and we never experienced street noise. The room was compact, but comfortable. The bathroom was totally remodeled and well decorated. The restaurant in the hotel was closed during the period we stayed at the hotel, so we did not have a chance to try it. We really grew to enjoy the central location...easy walking distance to many of the top sights and several subway stations. There were several good restaurants in the vicinity and a great place for breakfast only half a block away. Service was very good, with all requests promptly and enthusiastically fulfilled. We would often get a coffee in the library in the morning and appreciated the availability of bottled water in the library. Lots of renovation in the immediate area made for lots of scaffolding and congestion, but it didn't really impact our enjoyment of the hotel and location. We would happily recommend The Iroquois and would certainly stay there ourselves on any future trip to NYC.

title: “overall a decent room/bathroom/location”
text:
Bathroom was perfect, shower was great (good pressure, temperature control and a ledge for toiletries), mirror didn’t steam up and had a low light for night time usage. 
Bedroom was fine, bit of an odd layout which included a mirror behind the bathroom door which couldn’t really be used, a badly lit mirror in the hall and no other mirror or sufficient lighting in the bedroom. 
Housekeeping didn’t bother to service our room on the first day as we got up late, although on the second day they did at least leave a card informing us we needed to ask for the room to be made up at a later time. Also, they took the towels for washing even though we hung them up and let us run out of shower gel and toilet tissue by not replacing them regularly enough. 
Location was good in the sense that most of the areas were walkable and close to Penn station and subway, but bear in mind the area it’s in is nothing special and nowhere particularly close for brunch or drinks. 
We were looking forward to the excellent service they publicise, especially as it was our wedding anniversary and first time in New York, but the girl who checked us in was uninterested in our excitement and we got no thoughtful freebies. The doorman Doug gave us a welcome greeting every night as if he’d never seen us before which was funny at first and then annoying. 
Let down by the service, but would still stay there again though as overall a decent room/bathroom/location.

title: “Great service and fantastic roooms”
text: We were greeted with a smile at the Eventi and staff were very friendly and helpful, willing to go the extra mile if necessary. The hotel itself was very clean and tidy and if you sign up to be a Kimpton in touch member you get free internet. Restaurant food was good and rooms were lavish. For us it was a huge splash out to stay here as the nightly rate is quite expensive, but definitely worth it as transport is relatively close by and if you don't mind walking it's close to everywhere.

title: “Comfortable, convenient but not special”
text: I was in New York on business for four days, then my husband joined me for two days of fun. The bed was comfy, the bathroom was clean, the room service was prompt, the view is lovely and the location is convenient to downtown and the theatre district. My only complaints would be with service. The reservation system is strange. When I made my original reservation, I got a great price, but when my husband's schedule worked out for him to join me and I called back to extend my stay, I was given two choices: I could cancel my whole reservation and book 6 continuous days at a MUCH higher rate or I could make a new reservation for the two additional days at a more reasonable rate but there was no guarantee that I would get to keep the same room? The woman who checked me at the front desk was courteous and very helpful, but subsequent visits to the front desk were always a crap shoot...would the staff be in a good enough mood to help me? The doormen don't try to remember you. The doorman that I tipped the first day when he brought in my bags, who greeted me the next day as if he remembered me, still hassled me for my room key the following night when I went to get into the elevator. The worst service had to do with housekeeping. The first two days, no one bothered me when the Do Not Disturb sign was up, and when I left the room around 11am on those days, I called Housekeeping and told them my room was available to clean. The third day, at around 10:30am, Housekeeping CALLED ME, saying the Do Not Disturb sign was up, did I want any towels? I would expect that in a cheap motel, but the prices here do not reflect a cheap motel. When I complained, instead of apologizing, the staff made excuses. There is no excuse for calling a room when the Do Not Disturb sign is up. There are nicer hotels for this price. I would probably not stay here again.

title: “Luxury, Style and Service”
text: My wife and I stayed for two nights, and enjoyed our experience at the Chatwal immensely. The front desk team was very welcoming and professional. The rooms (a junior suite with a bedroom and a sitting room) were very stylish, with a warm leather desk that opened to a bright and functional vanity. The bathrooms, with some lovely fixtures and even high tech touches, will not be forgotten. The location was great, especially for a broadway visit, yet no outside sounds interrupted a good sleep. With the help of a very nice doorman, we were able to hail a cab at the hotel at midnight on Saturday! We will certainly return on our next NYC visit.

title: “A Boutique hotel with a BIG HEART!”
text:
I recently spent a few days at the Chatwal Hotel in NYC. Let me tell you that a few days was just not enough. I wish I could have stayed longer! 
Peter, the doorman, greeted us and right away I knew there was something special about this NYC hotel: THE PERSONAL TOUCH that is just lacking in some bigger hotels. Yes, the Chatwal is a smaller hotel, but the secret to its success is that it has a BIG heart. This is very evident in their staff. I have traveled all over and have never received such service from a wonderfully friendly, well-trained, professional staff. Brandon, head butler, came to our room to check on us personally and to see that we had everything we needed. Tall, stately, and with classic white gloves, he certainly represented the hotel well.
I talked mostly to two people at the front desk, Lance and Elizabeth, who were polished, knowledgeable, and again, very friendly. When I called for assistance, I think I always talked to them, too.
As to location, The Chatwal has a prime location, just a few blocks away from Times Square, and we were able to walk nearly everywhere we wished to go.
I took full advantage of our fabulous concierge, Nick, who was even able to get us tickets to “Phantom,” with very short notice. He also booked our tea time at the Palm Court and gave us some very good advice as to where to shop and sight see. He handed us directions that we could take with us, which we greatly appreciated.
Our suite was what I would call “modern classic,” and I would define that as, extremely comfortable, but very high tech. I don’t think I ever did figure out all the buttons on the toilet and the heated seat would actually spoil you. The TV in the bathroom is an interesting touch. The shower…okay, I’d like to live in the shower. It had a huge rain shower head and it the entire bathroom was done in black marble with silver chips that made you think of the moon against a dark sky. We also appreciated the Internet connection and wireless service.
When you stay at the Chatwal, don’t forget to book something in the spa, which is on the lower level. I had a pedicure and Lupe was just a joy to chat with…and she did a great job on my feet and toes!
We had a delicious breakfast one morning. Do NOT pass up the pastries. You can go back on your diet when you get home! The almond croissants and pain au chocolat were better than some I have gotten in fabled French restaurants. We had dinner one night there and I just had to ask who the chef was, since it was such a delightful meal. I was told that the chef is Jeffrey Zacharian and you may have seen him on Iron Chef, as a winner. I was also told that he is going to do a show for the Food Channel in the future. That should be interesting.
Our savior was the Chatwal’s Assistant Manager, George Petkovic. I think this man can be everywhere at once! His energy is boundless. He called us the morning we were scheduled to leave the hotel to inform us that our flight reservations had been cancelled for that evening. The airline had not given him a reason for the cancellation, but within 15 minutes he had gotten us alternative reservations. Since we had to leave a bit earlier than we planned, George had also booked a car for us. After doing all that, he came to our suite to check on us and offer his assistance, but we were all packed. The next thing I knew, we were safely in the car, heading for the airport. What amazing service!
As I said at the beginning, I wish I could have stayed longer and whenever I am in NYC, you may find me at the Chatwal Hotel.

title: “Chatwal is soo hot”
text:
I dislike New York...
But in the Chatwal you have a retro and luxury hotel. The bathroom is amezing with the big shower and everything to be to paradis.
And it's to 30 seconds to time square... You are in the best place to go on fifth avenue all is near, just walk fews minutes.

title: “Chic and modern”
text:
I'm not sure what a boutique hotel is anymore, but the Setai Fifth Avenue must surely rank as one. I was there on business but it would be a great hotel for couples who are exploring NY.
The lobby area is small but with very clean lines and a minimal feel to it. The service throughout the hotel is faultless. The rooms are small but again perfectly appointed for a luxury hotel. Don't expect a view you'll be overlooking another building, but hey when all's said and done you're in NY, very few hotels have a view. I miss the Plaza for that!
The bar area is ok, but again small and will get very busy. Even as a resident you'll need to be lucky to get a seat during the early evening.
I didn't eat dinner at the hotel, but I believe it was just the one restaurant. The breakfast was fine, if a little pricey. Nothing spectacular on that front.
Overall if you want to pay the price, it's a great hotel very well located, and I'd definitley stay there again for business or pleasure.

title: “My favourite hotel in my life”
text: We stayed in Setai for fashion week as we were invited to some parties and we thought the hotel was absolutely fantastic with huge room with nicest design ever,lovely restaurant,very profesional high top service,concierge manage to book us in recommended two Michelin star restaurant which is usually very busy and not easy to get in!We done lot of shopping in area,Empire state building is 5 minute walk and we had it as our window view.I will recommend to everyone who love luxury stay with amazing location and service.

title: “Could do better....”
text:
I was excited to try this hotel as it had many good write ups. But in all honesty there are many better quality 5 star properties in NYC. I stayed at the Setai as there was a UN event on and many of my usual hotels were fully booked. I had a one bedroom suite with views over the empire state building. 
The guys on the door as you arrive are not training to a high enough standard. They are more like security guys that proper 5 star door men. I asked for a cab on several times during my stay and on more than one occasion something distracting them and they forgot me. The bar on the ground level is OK but not 5 star by any means. The restaurant on the 2nd floor is better and breakfast is a good standard. The rooms are decorated in a modern clean style but the fittings are not of a high quality and already have a lot of damage. The carpets were a neutral cream colour and were stained badly. The location, versus the price, versus the experience dont add up! The gym is a room with no windows and no atmosphere. Its dark and not inspiring to train. This is a shame as there is some good equipment. I trained in there once and then went to another local gym. The Spa is ok but there are much better ones in less expensive hotels.
I lived in NYC on Park Ave for several years so know the city very well and this is not good value or a good enough standard. When i read back some of the other reviews i think this is a reflection of what folks are used to. If you are used to travelling and staying 5 star, this is not the hotel for you.

title: “Top Hotel”
text: Staff were very warm and friendly, rooms are exceptionally big. Location wise its very central less than two blocks from Macy's, five blocks from Grand Central Station/Times Square so really close to the hustle and bustle if you wanted to shop it was the ideal location. The checkin girl was friendly she asked was there a special occasion and my partner told her that is was my birthday, so whilst settling in to our room we got a knock on the door and we got a treat as a compliment from the hotel.

title: “This is how an Andaz should be...”
text:
The last time I was in NYC I stayed at the Andaz Wall. My experience there was not the best. This time I was again booked to stayed at the Wall St. location as I wanted to give the hotel a final try. However most of my meetings turned out to be in mid town and so I requested the Andaz Reservations Manager if she could transfer my booking to the 5th Ave location. She obliged immediately and also managed for them to honor my rate at Wall St. So this was already a good start. 
The hotel is pretty funky with an apartment feeling when you enter into the lobby. It is supposed to be a casual look with a relaxed attitude hotel. The hotel had upgraded me to a king room with the 5th ave view. I could see the NY Public library just outside my window. 
The room is HUGE as per NY standards. The ceiling was 12-14 feet giving it an even larger feel. The room was a bit sparsely furnitured but that was by design to give the room a larger feel and look. And hey, who goes to NYC and stays in the room? The bathroom also had very good amenities. Free wifi. Free bottles of water and free minibar. 
If you can get a room at Andaz 5th within 450 per night, its a steal and well worth it. I will surely be visiting them again.

title: “Boutique charmer”
text: The Andaz on 5th and 41st is an enjoyable stay. We had a 2 bedroom apartment which worked well for the 4 of us. Overall experience was very good, they do need to get their shower heads looked at - we had 2 bathrooms and both wall mounted showers were falling off- bad design, but also had foot bath and rain showers and they were great. Room snacks and non alcoholic drinks were included as were drinks at night in the reception area. Staff were friendly and helpful and location is good close to most things

title: “Rough patch, but turned out great”
text:
Despite a few bad experiences I would say most of the staff here are great and staying here can be a terrific experience. The hotel is very nice and modern. There are lots of little touches that set it apart, like providing free beverages when you arrive, free beverages and snacks in your room, and a free wine happy hour in the evenings. The restaurant was very good, with very good service. The location is also very central near the library and Bryant Park. 
Our check in was great. We arrived about noon and our room was not ready. We were given coffee and sparkling water while bags were checked in. Kelly took great care of us. Later Amy brought us to our room and also took great care of us. The room was larger, modern with a lounge couch, with a slight view of the Library down the street, but near the elevators. It seemed like a nice modern styled room, which we like. Then night time came. I could hear a high pitched noise from behind the walls that had been covered up by New York traffic during the day. And the noise was even worse deeper in the room and bathroom, away from the windows. I took my Ambient sleeping pill to try and block it out, but only got about four hours sleep and woke up to a splitting headache from the noise. Since we were staying three nights, I asked my husband to talk to the front desk about moving us to a new room. He was told the hotel was full and that they would send up an 'engineer' to look at the problem. Unless they were going to break through walls, I knew the problem could not be fixed by a handyman they would send up. I checked on Hyatt's website and found out they had lied to my husband because the hotel was not full. Next we both went down to the front desk to confront the man (sorry don't know his name) about the dishonesty and to let him know this problem was beyond a handyman repair problem. As I was trying to express my thoughts about the situation he kept saying 'I hear what you are saying, I hear what you are saying' which could not be true because he kept interrupting me and cutting me off from trying to tell him what I was saying. Finally he left and Kelly, the great and very professional lady who checked us in, came and took care of everything. She didn't question our need to move, tell us it was an engineering problem, lie about the hotel being full, or argue with us in any way. She just very gracefully took care of the problem. While we went out and enjoyed the day, she had our bags moved to another room (no high pitched noise, away from the elevators) and she also had a complementary bottle of champagne sent up. Kelly took a very bad situation that would have had us checking out of the hotel that day, and turned the rest of our stay into a wonderful experience. Instead of us being upset about the bad room and poor treatment, we instead had a very nice stay thanks to her. She is a real asset to the hotel, very professional and personable.
Regarding the staff and the wine happy hour, it is also spotty. Our first night, (Thursday Sept 27th), a lady was working the happy hour area. She saw us come in but she was having a conversation with a customer (about the California coast) so we sat there for over 10 minutes without any acknowledgement we were there. Finally my husband went into the lobby to ask for assistance and Amy, the nice and professional lady who took us to our room, came in and served us wine. The the lady who left us waiting for service gave us dirty looks after this, like we had done something wrong. The next night however, we went to the wine happy hour and received excellent service from a very friendly man. He was three times busier than the lady from the night before but was giving everyone great friendly service. 
Our waiter in the restaurant was also very good, professional, friendly and efficient. It was nice having a very good restaurant in the hotel, especially after exhausting days in New York.
This is a very good hotel with good amenities, some great service and some poor service. It is the extremes that can make it unpleasant. That said, when it works the hotel is a great place to stay.

title: “If it's luxury you seek....”
text:
then it's luxury you will find here. 
This hotel exemplifies everything you want in a luxury hotel. We stayed in the splash suite and it was worth every single penny. What a view! Overlooking the library, this room is simply stunning. My only complaint is that I had to leave!!
The beds are ridiculously comfortable. The room service was outstanding - I have never had HOT toast delivered to the room - it's kind of expected that by the time it gets to your room it will be luke warm at best - but the food here is exceptional and piping hot and delicious!
The staff are attentive, personable and very friendly. Nothing is too much trouble and my particular thanks go to John Donato for being so welcoming. 
There is nothing run down or dodgy about this hotel - from the decor to the location to the complimentary internet - this hotel should be your first choice. And if you can go the splash suite - do it!

title: “great stay”
text: me and my mam stayed here oct 2yrs ago it was 1st time,staff were lovely and hotel was great,we had to get cab in to times square but we didnt mind was only 10 dollars,was luvly hotel and helpful,staff were great checking on us:)would defo go back here

title: “Great hotel, a few flaws”
text:
We stayed for 6 nights at the Beacon, in a 2 room suite (BR plus sitting room/kitchen). The hotel is located close to the Metro, a few blocks from Central Park, a half hour walk across the Park to the Museum of Natural History and a little further to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It was a quiet oasis, particularly after the .shock of arriving at bustling Penn station. Rooms are well appointed and comfortable, and access to restaurants and food is easy (try Isabella's restaurant a few blocks away and buy great food at the supermarket opposite). The desk and concierge staff are efficient and helpful.
Only 3 weaknesses. The bathroom in the suite we were in, while adequate, was very small, one of the smallest we have ever experienced in many years of travelling - no place to leave toiletries, and it could be uncomfortable for some travellers - ask for a room with a large bathroom! Second, there was no washing up detergent provided requiring purchase of same, with a lot wasted at the end of the stay. And third, the airconditioning is old and very noisy, sufficient to wake one up during the night if you have it going in the same room - we shut the bedroom aircon down and relied on the second unit in the sitting room to keep the room cool, which worked well for us. If you are in a single room and a light sleeper, watch out for this.

title: “Our favourite NYC Hotel”
text: Two weeks ago week I stayed with my daughter in the Beacon Hotel for three nights. It was the fourth or even fifth time that I stayed in this hotel that feels like home. We love the location, two minutes fromt the subway, the neighbourhood, upper west side, Fairway across the street and the hotel itself that was renovated during the last few years.

title: “A fantastic experience”
text:
We stayed at the Beacon for 4 nights in October with our kids. The Beacon lived up to our expectations and more. Location is fantastic, with Central park 3 blocks away and the 72nd St subway station less than 3 minutes walk. The area is a bit more residential than Times square and we felt perfectly safe day and night without having to battle crowds. The Fairway market across the road is fantastic, with plenty to tempt the whole family and the kitchenette in the room is well stocked enough to prepare whatever treats you buy there. Directly below there is a great restaurant which serves generous helpings of simple but well executed meals, with a brilliant range of desserts (go the Key Lime Pie!). The staff are friendly and the rooms are spacious by NY standards, with everything you need from cable TV to coffee facilities. There is even a Century 21 about 10 minutes walk away for bargain hunting.
Bottom line - if you are travelling to NY with kids I would look very seriously at the Beacon. It's got everything you need: space, plenty of food options, easy transport, an amazing park that's an easy piggyback ride away and a very safe family friendly location.

title: “Lovely hotel, fantastic pool!”
text: I really enjoyed my stay at the Four Seasons Houston! The room was very nice, and I was very impressed by housekeeping. I was only going to be gone from the room for a couple of hours, so I called housekeeping to ask them to clean. When I returned, the room was perfect. The pool is very popular, so make sure to call ahead of time to reserve your lounge chairs. My only bad experience--it took forever for the valet to retrieve my car, and I was almost late for a luncheon.

title: “Great downtown property”
text: I agree with other reviewers that the hotel is a little dated. We spent a weekend in an executive suite. We were traveling with our little girl and were disappointed to find that there wasn't a seperate door to the sleeping area as shown in the picture on their website. They offered her a stuffed animal on check in. The hotel is in a great location for us to see various old friends. We enjoyed several room service meals. We also enjoyed the quick walk to Discovery Green and we picked up a few yummy treats at the grocery store next door.

title: “very good hotel, although fair for Four Seasons”
text:
The Four Seasons in Houston is a nice enough hotel however in desperate need of a face lift. It looks like a 1970's Hilton from the outside and through much of the hotel.
The beds are of course nice, like all other FS properties, however the room is dated. Nice size rooms however.
Bathroom, more shabby than all the other FS properties I have stayed at.
Pool area is quite nice, gym is fabulous. 
Breakfast was great at Quattro's however the coffee (lattes) were terrible yet still expensive!!

title: “Houston Gem”
text: Tis is the "go to" place to stay in Downtown Houston. The rooms are great, restaurant is very good, food very good, wine lust is excellent, and the prices are reasonable. I was upgraded from my usual suite to the "ambassador" room, which includes living room and dining room, small kitchen. Bathroom amenities are first class.

title: “Lovely property, slightly isolated”
text:
Hotel Icon is a well-designed hotel built in a former and historic bank building. The entry and lobby bar look both swanky and comfortable, and the bar cocktails are creative and well-made. My tenth floor room was spacious with large windows, a large desk and king size bed. The bathroom was equally large, with both soaking tub and shower. I appreciated some of the small details, like the reading lights on either side of the bed, free newspapers in the lobby, and ample towels in the bathroom. Only two small detractors to the room - the wifi signal was very weak, and the bathroom fixtures were a little worn. Otherwise the room was comfortable and well designed.
The hotel does offer a free shuttle to and from most downtown locations, which was very convenient since the property is on the edge of downtown and there isn't a ton to see or do in walking distance. The light rail runs right past the hotel, and while it's an easy connection on the rail to the museum district, the one rail line doesn't connect to much else.

title: “Great price for quality”
text:
I picked this hotel because we were staying for 3 nights and I wanted something comfortable and good decor. Not just a basic room. We also had tickets to see Oprah at the hobby performance center so we needed something in that area. Upon check in everyone was really helpful and nice. I booked one night on my credit card points and then the other 2 nights cash. We get the keys and get up to our room and it was right next to the elevator. We walk in the room and all we can hear is the dinging of the elevator and people getting on and off. We went back down and requested another room. They said it was because we booked through points that we didn't get a very good room. We then requested an upgrade which they gave us for an extra $15 a night. The only reason I write this is because if you book there cheapest room this is what you will get.
The good things are the room decor is awesome and my mom and I loved the bathroom because it was big with counter space for all of our makeup and curling irons. The bed was really comfortable and clean rooms. The other great thing is they offer a free shuttle to take you around downtown area. It will pick you up and take you anywhere you want to go. The breakfast buffet was really good. The location is one block from metrorail. Overall really nice property in good location. Would definitely recommend.

title: “Best Hotel, ever and I have stayed in a bunch of hotels in my life.”
text: Rita, Erica, Maktar and Al are just a few of the reasons I feel the Icon is the best. It is a beautiful hotel with all the luxeries and more that is expected of a high end hotel but the outstanding customer service and the individual attention is what keeps me coming back. Everyone makes you feel like a VIP. Can't wait to stay again.

title: “Nice hotel, close to everything”
text: My husband and I stayed here for our anniversary in 2007 and 2012. Our first experience was excellent and the staff treated us like royalty. At that time, they had a cute little London cab that shuttled you to downtown destinations and staff all around ready to help. We stayed on a Friday and could see the Friday night fireworks at the Astros game from our window. On our second stay (now under different management), the rooms are the same but there is far less staff to assist with bags or other things. We really like to uniqueness of the building's history and the decor is beautiful. The rooms are very nice and feel more romantic than a typical hotel room. Overall, we would definitely return and have recommended to friends & family.

title: “Bad People, Bad Follow Up”
text: My wife and I spent our second night at this hotel in January 2012. We stayed to celebrate a friend's birthday. We spent about 6 hours listening to a great band, Uncle Lucius. The waitress was spotty all night. There are not enough seats for the room. One per table. By the end of the night the waitress apparently thought we were blitzed and tried to run a non-itemized tab by us. I asked for the itemized tab and found that a 20% tip had been added in at her (the waitress) discretion. I followed up with an email to the general manager. He responded that he would take this response very seriously and would follow-up when all parties had been identified. We are now in June 2012. Apparently the investigation is quite serious and lengthy, as I have still not heard any follow-up from him. I don't know what that says to you...

title: “Hotel Sorella was AWESOME!!!”
text: This hotel sits in a great location with plenty of shopping, dining and night life. The hotel staff is FIRST CLASS from reservations, check-in, and check-out. The rooms are very sophisticated and they have lots of electrical outlets for phone chargers, computers, etc. Definitely a GREAT place to stay in Houston!!!!

title: “Beautiful hotel with the worst parking”
text:
I stayed at Hotel Sorella for a couple of days in April to attend a friend's wedding. First it was hard to find the actual hotel as it is in a complex with tons of shops and finding the actual entrance was a challenge. Then parking was an atrocity. When I left the garage and try to return late Friday or Saturday lines form going in and out and once in, I had to search for a parking spot. And the hotel isn't attached to the garage so imagine hauling your luggage quite a ways to the entrance of the hotel. Not fun! Especially in hot humid Houston!! That design plan didn't make any sense to me.
Once inside the hotel, check in was smooth and staff was friendly. The room was beautiful, clean and very contemporary. I used the gym one morning and it was adequate. I didn't eat at the continental breakfast as I was out and about during my stay. 
It was a decent stay overall but probably won't stay here again because I was traumatized by the parking situation.

title: “Hilton knock-off, not the real thing”
text:
We booked this hotel thinking it was a Hilton near the University (near where we have business) but instead it is a Hilton ON the University. BIG MISTAKE! 
Yeah ok I get the concept they've got to learn somewhere but wow if this is what they are learning lookout Hilton! First impressions mean a lot - pull up out front and the area is all trashy and some kind of muddy sludge. Drag bags up the handicap ramp (about 8 stair steps worth) through the mud and crud. Front desk was ok but the lobby stinks like a sewerline problem - elevator too. Slooooooow elevator. Then get to a Dirty room that hasn't been updated since the early 80's I'd say - it's got PINK furniture and gilded everything. Tiny tv - I'm not kidding like an RV size. Tiny tiny tiny bathroom.... did I mention tiny? Not even the newer curved curtain rods to keep the nasty shower curtain from sticking to you.
No diamond perks outside of the larger room - no dining chits or exec level. No pool. No gym onsite but you can use the one on campus (ah no thanks). $6/day parking which you have to get tokens from the front desk to use. 
Very noisy - lots of traffic noise & people milling around outside (oh yeah it's ON the university!). 
One and only plus - great Hilton bedding so I'll give them 1 dot for that. Other than that - just not a Hilton.

title: “Training hotel - nice concept.”
text:
This hotel is attached to the University of Houston and serves as a training ground for the school of hotel and restaurant management program. I liked the concept.
The room was nice and clean. The style was a little too conservative for my tastes, but it was not overwhelming either.
The staff was good, but not outstanding.
The parking was difficult (required tokens and the gates were having issues).
The walls were REALLY thin. I sneezed and the guy next door said "bless you." I also picked up my phone when his rang (then I heard every word of his conversation).
I was placed right outside the elevator even though I requested a quiet room away from the elevator.
The location is literally on a college campus - positive or negative depending on your personal tastes.
Overall my stay was good, but not outstanding.

title: “They even forgot to make an ordered wake-up call!”
text: The front desk staff was exceptionally rude. They even forgot to make an ordered wake-up call! The room was OK.

title: “OK, but does not meet Hilton standards.”
text: OK, but does not meet Hilton standards. Right on U. of Texas which has +'s and -'s but is aprox. $100 less then the Hilton Med. Center which is about 5 miles away. There's no gym on site, but you can use the campus gym. There's a good game room and fast food directly across from the hotel at the student center and the campus is nice, but the hotel rooms are old and don't meet the standards of the upgrades Hilton has been making. OK option for a business stay, but I wouldn't chose this a get away destination.

title: “Take it from me -- Could be better”
text:
For such a new hotel, this place is has some problems.I travel weekly for work and after around 100 nights at this hotel I switched. The shower heads, more times than not, were either broken or malfunctioning. The parking deck is a huge pain and typically the gate does not work when exiting. The air conditioning is horrible in most the rooms. Good luck getting a room to actually be 70 degrees in temperature. The food is absolutely horrible. There are like three items that are respectable, but not if you are paying for them on your own. If you are not a Platinum member DO NOT PAY FOR INTERNET. Their internet is absolutely terrible and should be considered a scam. If you get a room on the "club floor", plan on listenting to weights drop and people run on the treadmill on the floor above you. 
Aside from the internet, the worst part abotu the hotel is the air in the rooms. Its almost like the room is damp at times. Very uncomforting. 
On a positive note, most of the staff is pleasant to deal with. Tukai, one of the front desk associates, is awesome.

title: “Billed me 3 times!”
text:
Booked a room for my parents to stay near our house. They enjoyed the room, however the organisation at the hotel was terrible.
I initially booked online and pre-paid the room. We then decided to take the upgrade to club floor for an extra $30/night. For some reason they billed my card for the room (again) plus the upgrade fee. On check we were told this was a mistake, and the charge would be refunded (ok everyone makes mistakes). On check out - they said they would waive the upgrade fee for our trouble (good customer services I was thinking).
But on checking my credit card I was not refunded, and in fact charged again for the room. I called the hotel - who assured me they had made the refund, so I called the bank who confirmed they did charge my card again.
I am so far $1200 down for 2 nights at this hotel and no resolution in sight...

title: “Best hotel for the location!”
text:
If you find yourself in this part of Houston, the Westin Houston Memorial City is the place to stay. This modern, new hotel is well situated near major highways with easy access to local businesses. 
The rooms are VERY comfortable, while the heavenly bed isn't as special as it used to be.. I still get some of my very best night's sleep at Westin properties. 
The lobby area and front entrance can be pretty crowded during peak times in the morning, especially if there is a group meeting or conference going on. Skip trying to park in the garage and valet park
The Memorial City mall is connected to the hotel via a sky-bridge -- and provides a nice change of scene if you are on the road for business. Bring your ice-skates there is an indoor ice-ring!

title: “Excellent Hotel”
text: This hotel has some of the best service I have ever experienced. The staff excels in service, upon arrival, my room was not ready but was able to check in. They stored my luggage while I attended a session of my work conference the staff took my luggage to my room then found me in the conference room and handed me the keys. Still don't know how they remembered me because there were several checking in at the same time and we all received the same service. Job well done Westin.

title: “This a great place to stay, the entire staff is friendly and very helpful.”
text: My husband and I have been staying at the Best Western for 6 weeks, arriving on Monday and leaving on Friday while conducting business at our downtown office. The staff is so helpful, the rooms are clean and very roomy. This one of the best hotel I have stayed in and I travel a lot.

title: “My favorite Hotel in Houston”
text:
After years of having tried many different hotels in the Houston area I keep coming back to the Best Western Downtown. I am a Hilton HHonors Diamond member but I prefer this hotel to the Doubletree across I-45 and any other Hilton brand hotel in Houston.
It has by far the best is the sleep quality. It beats any and every hotel I have ever stayed in.
The rooms are large, very clean and come with high ceilings. They include bottled water and cookies.
The housekeeping staff is highly motivated and makes sure that you have a perfect stay.
Upon check in you will most likely meet a lady named 'Jo' at the front desk. 
Jo is friendly but not very outgoing and lacks a smile;yet she will take care of you and got this place under control.
I highly recommend this hotel to any traveller visiting Houston

title: “Great location”
text:
The Hilton Americas Houston is a large hotel in downtown Houston, within easy walking distance to Minute Maid Park for the baseball and the Toyota Centre for the basketball, as well as numerous quality restaurants and bars.
The hotel is one o the better Hilton Hotels I have stayed in, with large rooms, many with a view, and large comfortable beds.
The breakfasts and meals are great too.
Nice, friendly staff welcome you and look after you during the stay.
Although often busy with conferences, it caters well to all travellers - I like this hotel.

title: “10 Reasons why I'll book here again--Make that 11”
text:
Hotels always good on their websites, but this hotel exceeded our expectations. 
1) Set back from the main road....it felt very private and peaceful.
2) Outdoor area/parking lot always very well lit
3) Clean...and I mean really clean....bathroom, linens, rugs, furnishings....immaculate for this very picky traveler. 
4) Beautiful lobby and decor......I even took pictures of it. Warm, welcoming, big fireplace...
5) Staff deserves 10 Gold Stars...everyone very kind, warm, helpful. Hilton better hold onto this group of stellar employees. 
6) Super hot (as in temp.) coffee....from convenient caraffes in the hall at 6 a.m during the week. (We were on 7th floor). Excellent coffee from the Buffet Breakfast. 
7) Fresh, tasty and convenient Buffet Breakfast....made to order omeletes, sausage, bacon, bisquits w/ gravey, fresh fruits. every kind of bread/muffin/toast you can imagine. Beautiful dining area. 
8) Free Shuttle........Vallerie helped me out in a pinch and drove me to my designation (and picked me up) with a simple phone call. 
9) Pantry Pavillion....24/7 pantry if you need any last minute items (I needed pistachios and chocolate). 
10) Fresh baked and wrapped cookies for guests. 
11) Large desk area w/ perfect Internet connection.

title: “An absolutely wonderful hotel with welcoming staff”
text: This was our family's 4th stay at The Sherry-Netherland. We absolutely love it. Perfect location, updated rooms, great beds, incredibly clean, marble finishes in the bathrooms, flatscreen TVs, tons of bathroom amenities, etc. Our kids are made to feel welcome, each received a personalized gift bag with goodies inside. These are the little things that show the staff really cares. I can't praise this hotel and its staff enough. We will be back.

title: “Simply Awesome”
text: Went there for our 10th wedding anniversary and were completely taken aback by the staff and hotel. I've never in my life seen such quality service. You are made to feel as if you own the whole hotel. Everywhere you go, you are greeted with smiles and friendly comments. If you want a truly amazing experience and many wonderful memories and are going to NYC, put this hotel at the top of your list. Thank you to all the staff @ the Sherry ...there are too many of you to name specifically, but you were all awesome !! We'll be back ASAP.

title: “Great stay”
text: This hotel is a very good choice for anyone visiting New York. The staff are very nice and friendly, facilities are clean,and the rooms are a nice size. The only downside is that the continental breakfast dosn't have a good variety of food. The hotel is conveniently located to most venues.

title: “Very clean and nice room”
text: The room was very nice and clean. No view and windows could not open. Breakfast was nothing special and just standard.

title: “Wonderful Stay”
text: For my first trip to NYC I couldn't have picked a better place to stay. The location was perfect. The hotel was clean and quiet. The beds were divine after some busy days. The staff were great especially Steven who was particularly helpful and attentive. This is now my go to hotel for New York and won't hesitate to recommend it to friends.

title: “Wonderful find”
text: I recently stayed at the San Carlos Hotel for the first time. I made my selection based on desired location and Trip Advisor reviews (my usual "go-to" hotel in NYC was already booked for the weekend I wished to travel). I couldn't have been more pleased. The staff were friendly and very helpful. The room (two double beds) was large, nicely appointed and very clean. There was a roomy desk with comfortable chair and wi-fi was available free of charge. In addition to the two beds and desk, there was a comfortable upholstered chair with ottoman. A small alcove contained a refrigerator, microwave and coffeepot. The bathroom was roomy and modern. The elevators was very efficient with very little waiting time no matter the time of day. The continental breakfast was complimentary and was served just off the main lobby from 7-10 AM daily. Yogurt, sweet rolls, bagels, toast and cereal as well as coffee, tea and orange juice were available. By NYC standards, the room rates were very reasonable. I think I have found a new "go-to" hotel for my visits to NYC!

title: “Lived Up to Expectations”
text:
My wife and I chose this hotel based on its overwhelmingly positive reviews on this site and others, and it lived up to expectations. We came to New York City to celebrate our 25th wedding anniversary and see all of the typical sites - from the southern tip and the WTC to Central Park - and this hotel's location was perfect. Times Square was two blocks away, all the main theatres were 2-4 blocks away, and major subway stops were also only a couple of blocks at most. And because of it's nearness to the theatre district, you had a plethora of restaurants to chose from.
The hotel itself was immaculate and in a very safe area, surrounded by other botique hotels, restaurants, and nice bars - always felt safe. The rooms were large enough, for NYC, and the ammenites were great - other than the fact that you had to call for ice; no ice machines. Be sure and check out the Tavern's Keep cocktail bar on the first floor - they serve 1800-1920s era classic cocktails, with top notch ingredients and great presentation.
The front desk staff was good enough, but Vanessa, the Chief Concierge was fabulous. She took care of all of the tasks I needed done in advance - arranging car service for us from Newark, getting a reservation at one of the finest restaurants in NYC for our anniversary, printing out Empire State Building tickets, etc. She even took care of a complimentary bottle of wine and chocolates for our anniversary - very nice.
The combination of location of the hotel, cleanliness and ammenities, and professionalism of staff made The Iroquois Hotel the perfect choice. I would not hesitate to stay there again, and Vanessa helped us make our 25th wedding anniversary a VERY special occassion.

title: “Convenient location - comfy small space”
text: The Iroquois was recommended to my husband and I by family who had stayed there. We found the room to be small, but adequate for our needs - how much time do you spend there anyways - you are in New York City. The room did not have a fridge, but you can request one. The staff was friendly and helpful - ice arrived promptly when requested. It was July and the air conditioning worked perfectly. We were out and about from early morning to later in the day and did not use the hotels amenities, but heard from other guests that the restaurant was lovely. The location was just around the corner from Times Square, but noise was not an issue. We enjoyed the five nights we stayed at The Iroquois and we would definitely stay there again on our next trip to New York.

title: “Cramming a lot of service into a small space”
text:
This hotel is located in the very centre of midtown manhattan. (44th between 5th and 6th ave).
As such it is ideally situated for Grand Central and the Theatre District.
If you don't mind the walk, Central Park is not too far and hardcore shoppers will go crazy for the number of high end stores around this area (Macy's is 10 blocks south and 2 avenues over).
We however, found that many of the places we wanted to visit, required a short cab ride (Chelsea, West Village, Lincoln Center). Cabs are easy to get and inexpensive - plus you can pay by card at no extra charge these days.
If you are looking for a relaxing slice of NY life, this area is to be avoided. If you enjoy hustle and bustle - the centre of the action is right here. Bear this in mind when choosing a room in the hotel - if you are at the front of the building, you need to be high up.
We stayed in two different rooms. The first room was a classic room with 2 double beds in the middle of the hotel on the 4th floor - it had views of a burnt out building and (because of the buildings shape) also afforded an excellent view into a neighbouring guests' room.
This room had a small thin bathroom and a strange bath/shower arrangement with sliding doors and this made it difficult to get in and out. The decor however, was extremely nice. 
We extended our stay and moved to a Suite at the front of the hotel on the 8th floor. This consisted of a lounge with two sofas, a desk and two armchairs, a chest of drawers, some tables and a large TV plus mini fridge. Then a bedroom with a US King / UK superking bed, plus an armchair with footstool, a chaise long style bench, a chest of drawers, a couple of tables and another large TV. Also a very thin closet. The bedroom leads onto a beautifully decorated bathroom with a separate show and jacuzzi bath and lots of towels plus robes.
We loved the mattress and linens in both of the bedrooms we stayed in. I will be investigating purchasing the mattress for our new house.
One major drawback for us, was the low lighting levels in both of these rooms. At some point in the past, the hotel decided to remove the central light fixture from each room, leaving beautiful but somewhat impractical mood lighting as the only light source (lamps, picture spots etc). At times we even turned the TV on to provide more lighting! In our first room, we asked for an extra lamp - which was some help but I believe they use low wattage/energy saving bulbs, so not a complete solution.
The service in this hotel was excellent. Nothing was too much trouble for the friendly and resourceful staff. This was particularly helpful when I was taken ill and required special considerations.
Other small but nice features of this hotel, are the switches on the back of the door, which can be turned red for DO NOT DISTURB or green, so that a member of staff can ring your doorbell for service.
The library downstairs is very small but comfortable and there is a good selection of books/papers, plus computers with internet. There is also free and speedy wifi throughout the hotel.
We would definitely stay again if we needed a comfortable bed in midtown again.

title: “Boycott this hotel”
text: The day after the hurricane struck, leaving Manhattan below 26th street without power, water, wi-if, 3G and phone signal. I walked up to the Eventi Hotel on 6th Avenue around 3pm, they had power, a phone signal and water, from my apartment s few blocks away, i didn't. I asked for a room, they had none, fair enough. But I then asked if I could plug my phone in to make a single call as i had no way of charging it at home. The doorman absolutely refused. I clarified that I didn't want to charge the phone merely make a single call. Once again, stony faced refusal with no explanation. I wasn't rude or aggressive, i'm a smartly dressed Brit in my mid 40s. So anyone who's admired the friendliness of staff at the Eventi on sites like tripadvisor should appreciate that the smiles disappear if they're not taking your money and whilst the rest of the city is working together in the time of crisis they stand out as an outpost of snobbery and selfishness.

title: “Wonderful staff at this hotel”
text: Great hotel, clean room, very comfortable bed and friendly/helpful staff. We took an upgrade for an extra $100 and it was great to have a little extra room. Kirk, an excellent staff member, went out of his way to be helpful and we very much appreciated the extra mile. It was obvious to us that the hotel staff thinks customer satisfaction is a priority.

title: “Great place”
text: We arrived in the middle of the night and the Kimpton employees made us feel right at home. I stay at boring hotels all the time so when I get the chance to stay at a Kimpton, it's always a pleasure. I didn't want to check out the next day!

title: “Luxury begins with Service”
text:
My husband I had a get away to New York 8/24-26 and we stayed at the Chatwal based on a recommendation from a good friend that frequents the hotel. We had high expectations given the trusted recommendation and that Joel Freyburg's (the GM) assistant assured my husband that we would be treated like VIPs for our special trip. I have to say that I was very let down. First let me recognize the hotel for all that was great about it. The location is fantastic- close to Time Square but on a quiet street that allows you to escape. The design and furnishings in the hotel were top notch. The hotel had an art deco feel in the lobby and the room was well appointed and the furniture, appliances/technology was first class. There was a TV built into the bathroom vanity which surprisingly I enjoyed. There was a rain shower and also a hand held- very nice shower but more to tell on that in a moment.... And my favorite feature was the toilet. I know it sounds crazy but the seats were heated and the bidet was perfect! And lastly the spa was great and my massage was excellent. 
So where did it fall short you ask? The service (with the exception of the bell and door men who were great). All presented a friendly aim to please spirit and the white gloves were a nice touch but the service fell apart in the execution. It started upon my arrival. Our room wasn't ready which was fine so I asked the concierge for a spa recommendation. I did not know they had a spa in the hotel and his response was "Well what about our spa, is it too expensive?". Rule number one, never assume anything about someone's finances. I ended up going to the spa in the hotel and that is when the second incident occurred. After my massage I asked if I could go up to my room in the spa robe. The spa agreed and called to the front desk to have my keys brought down to the spa so that I would not have to go to the main lobby. We waited for 25 minutes for my key that never arrived (after 2 additional calls to the front desk) and finally I had to go and get my own key in my robe. The third incident was that I did not know how to make the shower water warm (not the hotel's fault) so on the first night of our stay we called for help and they said they would send someone up. After waiting and hearing nothing I took a cold shower. I called early that next morning and the engineer was not in, so once again I could not get help with the shower until after we were scheduled to leave for our breakfast reservation so I took my second cold shower that am. I am assuming that the engineer did fix the shower because it worked great that evening but after 2 cold showers you would think someone would let us know that it was handled and ensure that we knew how to use the shower appropriately. At this point I was done. 
The final kicker for me was that when asked if we enjoyed our stay the day of our departure, I politely expressed my dissatisfaction and the lady at the front desk kindly apologized and asked to make it up to us on our next visit. While I believe she was sincere, offering to rectify an issue on some future date that may never occur is a service faux pas. You can not assume you will get a second chance to make something right. Especially not after failing the first time at $~600 per night.

title: “Outstanding Boutique Hotel”
text: My wife and I came to NYC on our annual Broadway trip and stayed at The Chatwal for our first time. It was a tremendous experience, from the vintage 1930s style to the beautiful decor and accouterments. However, the best part by far are the people. Elizabeth at the front desk is both professional and warm - a difficult balancing act. All the front desk people mirror this style. Nick at the concierge desk was helpful, friendly, very professional and eager to assist. The butler, the bellmen and the doormen all reflect a bias towards friendly service. Everyone made us feel very much at home. Be sure to stop for dinner at the Lamb's Club, Geoffrey Zakarian's outstanding restaurant, accessed from within the hotel. We were lucky enough to spend some time with him. Again, food and ambience at the highest level. All-in-all, a wonderful place to stay - and within easy walking distance from the theaters.

title: “The NICEST Hotel we have ever stayed at world wide!”
text:
Unbelievable attention to detail from the service (with white gloves) to the features of the room to the complimentary health club. Wave resistant pool and steam rooms included. Electronic window shades, bidets with heated seats, piped surround sound, turn down service, complimentary shoe shines and ironing. The breakfast in the lobby restaurant was superb. The upstairs bar is cozy and quiet.
And literally 1/2 block off Times Square, the location was only surpassed by the service and amenities.

title: “Best Hotel In New York”
text: Stayed at the Setai for one week . Booked a Capella King Room and got upgraded to the Capella king with view of Empire State Bld. Wether you had the view or not would not bother me but do ask for a high floor, you will still hear some noise from the street but it's that buzzy sort of NY noise that you learn to appreciate after a while.this Hotel is absolutely First Class in every way. The rooms are Huge by New York standards and the modern decor is very classy. Beds are ultra comfortable, the women will love the massive wardrobe and bathroom and everything you can ask for is in the room, nespresso coffee machine , fridge full of complimentary sodas , water etc... After walking the streets of New York all day it is an absolute delight to come back to this fantastic room. Being a relatively new hotel every conceivable thing is new and works . Internet is free and fast. The gym is well appointed , plenty of brand new equipment, free water and fruit.we did not dine in the hotel there are just too many other great places to eat in New York. We did have room service one evening and it was absolutely delicious. What really makes this hotel is the staff. They are genuine, friendly , courteous and treat everyone with a warm smile. From the doorman to the front desk to concierge, the cleaning staff, the charming man who fills your fridge up every day. I could not say how pleasant they all are . The management of this hotel are doing a wonderful job and everyone should be congratulated . In nNew York you get what you pay for so don't be put off by having to pay $700-$850 a night for these types of rooms , they are worth every cent.thankyou Setai , we will definitely be staying here again when we come to New York.

title: “Exceptional Hotel”
text: If you want an oasis in the midst of NYC whilst being close to the action this is your hotel. Stayed for 3 nights and wished it could have been 3 weeks. When you are comparing top class hotels it is the little things that count - complementary pressing of shirts and suits, free soft drinks from the mini bar, in room espresso machines - i.e. you were not constantly feeling like you were being charged additionally. The great service extended to booking meals and tours. Honestly great position, value and rooms to die for.....

title: “5 Star Experience”
text: This was truly a 5 star boutique hotel. Room service all night long with outstanding food. Te concierge arranged for pizza delivery to my room at 5:30am after a night out at te bars. Hotel bar had a great selection of beers, and live Jazz. The room were straight out of a magazine, with attendants on each floor stocking the fridges, cleaning up, and making sure everything was spotless upon my return to the room. For a weekend trip to NYC, this was the perfect hotel.

title: “Immaculate and comfortable”
text: Professional and friendly staff, beautiful modern facilities and great location. Highly reccommended! The Bar on 5th had really yummy cocktails and a friendly staff, with live Jazz in the evening. In room fridge always stocked with complementary waters and soft drinks, and in-room expresso machine was great. Excellent for business, family or romantic travel as it felt very private, with apartment-like rooms. Will go back for sure!

title: “Andaz 5th Ave Splash Suite.....wow again”
text: This time I visited end of July and decided to upgrade to the Splash suite. Re: special occasion, girlfriend from college, friends visiting at the same time, etc. Definitely a splurge but boy was it worth it! The room is breath taking......huge. Larger than most manhattan millionaires' condos....seriously. The couch in the main living area could accommodate 5 to 6 people easily, and of course there was a work area and other sitting chairs. The bedroom was on the far opposite end of the suite, separated by the bath area; there was a great view of the NY public library and the room was relatively large...flat screen & corner love seat. As for the bath area, it was amazing. It had the same modern, gorgeous shower found in the other andaz rooms, and of course a large soaking tub in the center room surrounded by two huge closets. My overall impression: phenomenal. However, be sure to lower the blinds depending on how much of an exhibitionist you are:)

title: “Interesting, contemporary room”
text: I liked the Andaz hotel... very contempory room with touch pad controls for lights, shades, etc... not fancy, but somewhat chic/modern. The shower required a personal tutorial with 3 modes... foot bath, rain shower and hand shower. I liked how the non-alchoholic mini bar items and internet are included... I don't like to be nickle and dimed in a nice hotel... just bake it into the price. Also liked the wine hour in the evening -- nice touch before you go to dinner. The bed was good -- soft comforter, plenty of pillows... pretty firm. I was also there for an all day meeting... the space was good and the luncheon was well done. Location was good -- in the heart, but not too busy. I would recommend it/ go back.

title: “Amazing View!”
text: We stayed at this hotel the other night to attend a wedding at the NY Public Library which is directly across the street. We had an amazing view of midtown Manhattan and, in particular, the library. The lobby of the hotel is small and has a residential and very welcoming feel to it. The staff is amazing - they can't do enough for the guests. I highly recommend a stay at the Andaz at least once for the view alone! We ate brunch in the hotel on Sunday morning, mostly for convenience. The food was good but there are better places (and less expensive places) if you are willing to venture out of the midtown area. I was advised to ask for a king room with a view for the next time to assure the fantastic view.

title: “New, stylish and comfortable”
text:
